Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The role of phyllosphere microbiomes in plant species coexistence and plant-pathogen interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Microorganisms are species that are so small that you cannot see them with the naked eye. Microorganisms live all over the surfaces and inside of every type of larger organism on the planet, forming what is known as the "microbiome" of the larger hosts. This research will focus on the microbiomes of plants, which have profound impacts on plant health and performance. This research will focus on how microbiomes affect resistance of a host to another microorganism: a disease-causing fungus. By experimentally manipulating combinations of microbiomes, host species, and whether or not the disease-causing fungus is present, the researchers will be able to find out how microbiomes affect the ability of different plant species to compete with one another and to resist disease. By growing microbes found in natural microbiomes and by using state-of-the-art DNA sequencing approaches, they will begin to identify how important microbial players affect plant health. This project will involve the training of a graduate student in cutting-edge bioinformatics techniques. Because one outcome of this work will be to identify how and whether inoculating plants with the right microbiome protects against disease, the results from this work will also contribute to the development of new approaches to fighting costly pathogens in crops, and to helping land managers promote biodiversity in natural systems.


In the past three decades, the plant-soil feedback framework has been used to achieve theoretical and empirical breakthroughs. Phyllosphere microbial communities, which reside in or on aboveground plant tissues, are similarly diverse, but current research suffers from an inability to connect presence and identity of phyllosphere microbes to larger ecological questions. In this project, researchers will test how pathogen infection alters the fitness and growth outcomes of con- vs. heterospecific phyllosphere microbial communities, with a focus on the fungal constituents of these microbiomes. Next-generation sequencing technologies will be combined with culture-dependent approaches to study the mechanisms of fungal community assembly in the phyllosphere. Functional trait data will be collected on select fungal cultures as metrics of plant-fungal and pathogen-fungal interactions. This trait-based approach will then be used to determine whether specific traits of the fungi measured in the lab can be used to understand their abundance and role on plants. This body of work has the potential to expand the scientific community's understanding of phyllosphere community assembly, and the mechanisms by which different phyllosphere communities inhibit or facilitate plant-species coexistence on their own or in conjunction with pathogens.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Previous research on aboveground microbiota in plants (i.e., the phyllosphere) has primarily focused on direct fitness effects and roles of microbial community members for hosts of a single species, but these microbiomes have received less attention for their potential role in mediating plant-plant interactions and species coexistence. In early dissertation work, I developed a novel method to experimentally manipulate phyllosphere inoculum sources across multiple plant host species and test their role in mediating plant-plant interactions. In one experiment, I found that all four plant species tested experienced relatively stronger antagonistic effects when inoculated with microbiota from their same species than when inoculated with microbiota from another species. These early findings indicated that phyllosphere microbiota may be an underappreciated stabilizing force on plant-plant competitive dynamics in wild plant communities.

My Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant allowed me to extend these initial findings to identify which microbes in the phyllosphere inoculum are driving these plant-plant interaction outcomes. Specifically, I performed a new experiment using a similar manipulation of phyllosphere inoculum as before but included a pathogen enemy treatment. Pathogen enemies may alter the outcome of phyllosphere effects on plant-plant interactions in a context-dependent manner.

For one of the three species tested (Liatris spicata), I found that there was a benefit to host growth when inoculated with phyllosphere microbiota from their same species relative to microbiota from another species, but only when dually exposed to a pathogenic enemy. This result stands in comparison to my earlier findings where inoculation with microbiota from another species was more beneficial than inoculation with microbiota from the same species. The key difference was the presence of the pathogen. When Liatris was exposed to a pathogen enemy, the outcome of inoculation with microbiota from the same host species flipped, and it became more beneficial. I am currently sequencing the fungal communities present in the inoculated, experimental plants, as well as those present in the inoculum sources. My research will show how the interactions between different plant species, and their respective phyllosphere microbiomes, are affected when they are conditionally exposed to a generalist enemy. I am currently analyzing these data and will be preparing a manuscript for publication. 

Lastly, the Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant also gave me the opportunity to attend a workshop on bioinformatics, where I gained skills on the processing of microbial community sequencing datasets.
